titleStmt.title: H. C. Hancock to Thomas E. Bramlette
CWG6042

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Thomas E. Bramlette: Governor's official correspondence file, petitions for pardons, remissions, and respites 1863-1867

body.p: To the Gov of Kentucky your petitioner H C Hancock of ^allen^ County Kentucky would beg leave to State that Sometime in the year 1857 your petitioner had a dificulty which resulted in a fight with Job Eddins in which your petitioner unfortunately pulled out one of said Eddins eyes Your petitioner and the said Eddins were drunk at the time of the fight or it would not have accured -- Your petitioner has since that time made all the reparation to the Said Eddins in his power by paying him in money the damages he was able to pay Since which your petitioner has been indicted in the allen circuit court & which is now pending He asks an interposition of your excellencys power of pardon to be releaved from said prosecution -- If the penalty announced by law & your petitioner was able to pay it went for the benefit of the unfortunate man he would say nothing but under the circumstances he pays the extention of your power in his behalf and as in duty bound &c
Sworn to & subscribed before me by H. C. Hancock this 26th day of December 1864
From the representations of this case made to me & from my knoweldge of the parties I believe the case justifys Your excellencys interposition

G M Mulligan
John J. Gatewood

The undersigned Job Edins states that he is the man that the Petitioner H. C. Hancock had the difficulty with and that at the time of said difficulty both the parties were drunk and did not know what they were doing. He states the he unfortunately had his eye puled out in the fight ^or hurt so it went out^ but Hancock has paid and satisfied him in a pecuniary point of view for the damage he done and satisfied me as far as he could and it is just and right for your excellency to interpose as asked in his petition

Job ^his X mark^ Edins
attest
N K Patin Esq
This petition is premature not trial having been had -- & is therefore refused

The undersigned citizens of Allen County and acquanted with the circumstances of the difficulty between H C Hancock and Job Eddins State that in our estimation it is acase requiring relief as prayed for in the foregoing petition

William Mansfield
J, H, Butler
J, F, Williams
W, W, Walker
A Dean
J. W. Martin
